title:
Mixed Gauge-Global Symmetries, Elliptic Modes, and Black Hole
  Thermodynamics in Ho\v{r}ava-Lifshitz Gravity
abstract:
Physical theories are largely dictated by their symmetries. One important
conjecture in this vein is that a consistent quantum gravity theory may not
possess a global symmetry, but rather only local gauge symmetries, a conjecture
which has recently been extended to generalized global symmetries.
Historically, this conjecture arose from a heuristic argument using black hole
thermodynamics and was recently proven to hold in AdS/CFT. In Horava-Lifshitz
gravity, a presumed consistent theory of quantum gravity for which there is
strong evidence for both black hole thermodynamics and a holographic
construction, spacetime is endowed with a preferred dynamical spacelike
foliation. The theory has a leaf reparameterization symmetry that is neither
global nor local gauge, hyperbolic and elliptic equations of motion, a lack of
splittability, and universal horizon black hole solutions. The
reparameterization symmetry is "mixed": it is a local symmetry in one
coordinate that remains global on each leaf. More broadly it is an example of
both unfree and projectable gauge symmetries. We show how the corresponding
charge, which has previously not been considered thermodynamically, coupled
with the other features above, resolves some outstanding tensions. Hence this
mixed symmetry is not precluded by horizon thermodynamics, but is instead an
integral feature. This expands the types of symmetries in quantum gravity
compatible with black hole thermodynamics.
